title: we boost the immune system?
intro: Can ginger shots, turmeric and cold water swimming boost your immune system? Georgie and Neil hear from experts and teach you some vocabulary.
this_week_question: How many colds does the average adult get in the UK each year?
Listen to the programme to hear the answer.

vocab.desc: an expression used in spoken English in order to avoid bad luck
minor illnesses that affect your nose
an expression used in conversation to ask someone to say something to support your opinion
(something) likely to be negatively affected by something

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Georgie.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I'm Neil. In this programme we're talking about the immune system, which is the body's natural defence against getting ill. Now, Georgie, is there anything you do to boost your immune system?

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: Yes. I try to eat lots of oranges, which apparently have lots of vitamin C, and there are lots of things people do to try to improve their immune system, and stay healthier, like eating certain foods, taking vitamins, or even activities like swimming in cold water. We'll find out how useful some of these techniques are in today's programme.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But first, Georgie, a question. We all know the common cold – now, that’s the illness that makes you cough and sneeze, have a sore throat and headache. But how many colds does the average adult get in the UK each year? Is it:

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: Eight would be a lot. I'm going to go with a) 2-3 colds a year.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, we'll find out at the end of the programme if you're right. Now, many people can become ill over the winter with diseases like colds, flu and Covid-19. Host of BBC Radio 4 programme Inside Health, James Gallagher, gathered some experts to talk about immune systems, and he started off by asking whether they'd had more illnesses than usual this winter.

transcript.author: James Gallagher
transcript.text: Hello! [Hi.] Right, how has everyone been this winter? Because I've had a rotten one and I have felt constantly ill since about November. John?

transcript.author: John Tregoning
transcript.text: I have not had anything yet, touch wood .

transcript.author: James Gallagher
transcript.text: OK, let's see what I can infect you with by the end of the show. Margaret?

transcript.author: Margaret McCartney
transcript.text: I was pretty unwell in September. I had what I presume to be Covid. But I've been alright since, mild snuffles aside.

transcript.author: James Gallagher
transcript.text: Eleanor, I really need someone to back me up .

transcript.author: Eleanor Riley
transcript.text: No, sorry, I've been absolutely 100% tickety-boo .

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: Unlike James, Professor John Tregoning hasn't been ill. John uses the expression touch wood , which is an informal phrase said in order to avoid bad luck.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Doctor Margaret McCartney was unwell in September but has only had a few snuffles since. Snuffles is an informal word used to describe minor illnesses that affect your nose. We can also say sniffles .

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: Host James is surprised that nobody has been ill, and says to Professor Eleanor Riley ' back me up '. If you ask someone to back you up , you are asking for them to say something which supports your opinion.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But Eleanor has had a healthy winter too. She's been tickety-boo , which is an informal phrase meaning everything's fine or in good order.

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: Throughout the winter, many people try different techniques, like taking supplements or eating certain foods to boost their immune system, to improve their body's natural defences against disease. Host of BBC Radio 4's Inside Health James Gallagher asks doctor Margaret McCartney whether some of these products are successful.

transcript.author: James Gallagher
transcript.text: OK quick-fire round Margaret. Echinacea?

transcript.author: Margaret McCartney
transcript.text: No.

transcript.author: James Gallagher
transcript.text: Turmeric?

transcript.author: Margaret McCartney
transcript.text: No.

transcript.author: James Gallagher
transcript.text: Ginger shots?

transcript.author: Margaret McCartney
transcript.text: No.

transcript.author: James Gallagher
transcript.text: This is a very, very good quiz! What about the stuff you squirt up your nose when you're at the beginning of an infection?

transcript.author: Margaret McCartney
transcript.text: Interesting, but not any better than normal saline spray – just salt water.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: In fact, according to Margaret, there isn't enough evidence that many popular health products can actually change the way your immune system works.

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: Another popular health trend in the UK is cold water swimming. People who swim in cold water say it's good for their mental health, and they also believe it makes them less likely to get ill during the winter months.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But scientists aren't sure about the benefits of cold water swimming for the immune system yet, as Professor John Tregoning explains to BBC Radio 4’s Inside Health.

transcript.author: John Tregoning
transcript.text: The social element actually is really important. It probably is beneficial to do. You reduce stress and cortisol dampens the immune system, so actually if you're stressed then maybe you are more prone to infection. And that may be why that benefit of being with people, nice people that you like in nice places, is helping. But I don’t think it's unique to cold water swimming. I think you could probably get it from dancing or singing or going for a run.

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: John says that cortisol, a chemical associated with stress, dampens the immune system. Here, dampens means makes weaker. We also have a common expression ' dampen someone’s spirits ' which means to make them less enthusiastic about something.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: John says that there is evidence that people who are stressed are more prone to infection. If you're more prone to something, it’s more likely to happen to you.

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: It could be that cold water swimming reduces stress, and so it helps people’s immune systems work well. But there are lots of other activities that could have the same effect, and help people have fewer colds over winter.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Which reminds me of my question, Georgie. I asked how many colds the average UK adult has a year.

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: And I said 2-3.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And that is the correct answer, so well done!

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: Thank you! OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned, starting with touch wood , which is an expression used, often in speech, to avoid bad luck.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Snuffles , or sniffles , are minor illnesses that affect your nose.

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: If you ask someone to back you up, you want them to say something to support your opinion.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: The expression tickety-boo means fine and in good order.

transcript.author: Georgie
transcript.text: If you dampen something you make it weaker. And the expression dampen someone's spirits means you make them less enthusiastic about something.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And if you're more prone to something, it's more likely to happen to you.
